thread.title: Blue Jays playing under protest after controversial call in ALDS Game 5
thread.title_full: Blue Jays playing under protest after controversial call in ALDS Game 5 | Toronto Star

author: Robin Levinson King
title: Blue Jays playing under protest after controversial call in ALDS Game 5
text:
Photos View photos zoom With everything on the line, the Blue Jays are demanding that a controversial play be overturned and the team is now playing Game 5 under protest.
The team will ask Major League Baseball to review the play and, if overturned, the game would be replayed from the seventh inning.
This is what happened:
The Texas Rangers were awarded a run when a routine throw back to the mound hit the Shin-Soo Choo’s bat, allowing Rougned Odor to score — and give Texas a 3-2 lead and sending an uproar through the Rogers Centre.
Odor was on third base when Jays catcher Russell Martin attempted to throw the ball to pitcher Aaron Sanchez.
But the ball hit the end of Choo’s bat, rolling down the third base line.
It appeared as if the umpire had already called time before Odor crossed the plate. The umpires reviewed the play and ruled that the interference was incidental, and that the run counted.
Some infuriated fans in the stands began throwing beer cans onto the field and there were reports that a baby had been hit.
Players were taken off the field, while manager John Gibbons consulted with the umpires, resulting in an 18-minute delay. Gibbons is now protesting the game.
